fn.p: J.B., M.J.D. and D.A.R. conceived the project. M.J.D. and E.F. designed and performed flow cytometry experiments. R.M. generated and processed scRNA-seq data. M.F. and D.A.R. developed methodology. M.F. developed python software and analysed scRNA-seq data. M.F., M.S. and M.J.D. analysed FACS data. Visualisation M.F. All authors interpreted data and designed experiments. M.F. and D.A.R. developed the mathematical models with contributions from M.S. M.F. constructed the global landscape model and performed related analysis. M.S. performed the pulses analysis and constructed the related model. M.F., J.B. and D.A.R. wrote the manuscript with additional material from M.S. All authors reviewed and edited the manuscript.
The authors declare no competing or financial interests.

caption.title: Attractor Clusters in Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Data Reveal Discrete Cell States During Neural Development.
caption.p: A. Schematic diagram of neural tube patterning regulated by the Shh gradient.
B. Schematic of in vitro differentiation of mESCs and timing of the scRNA-seq data collection (D, Day).

C. Example of the outward clustering methodology illustrated by the analysis of the late time points (D5-D7). (Left) 2D PCA projection of cells that express one of the marker genes Olig2, Nkx2.2 and Shh. (Middle) PCA projection from d-dimensional effective gene space using the d most significantly differentially expressed genes (see SI Sect. S2.1) between the 3 samples of cells (here d = 96). Cells are clustered using Leiden clustering with fine resolution and coloured accordingly. (Right) The fine Leiden clusters are merged based on their molecular identities.
D. The most significantly differentially expressed genes distinguishing the 3 samples of cells shown in C (left panel).
E. Schematic diagram summarising all the ACs and possible transitions between them identified in the scRNA-seq dataset at 500nM SAG across all time points (D3-D7).
F.-H. Identification of early ACs (D3-D4) and transitioning cells between them labelled with -Trans.
F. PCA projection of cells from D3-D4 samples showing the early ACs.

G. Dot plot indicating the expression of markers used to identify the early ACs. The size of the circle represents the percentage of cells in the AC and the intensity of shading indicates the mean expression of the gene.
H. The proportion of cells (in percent) in each AC and transitioning clusters at the early time points (D3-D4).

I.-K. Identification of late ACs (D4-D7) and transitioning cells between them, labelled as -Trans. Same figures as in F.-H. using cells from the D4-D7 samples. The D8 sample is not displayed, it predominantly contains MNs, V3 neurons, MNDiff cells, and p3 cells.

L. Extraction of the group of adjacent ACs, Early p3, p3 and FP, that comprise the ventral sub-landscape, visualised in 2D LDA space (see also SI Fig. S3A-B). Histograms for each linear discriminant score (i.e the dot product of the data vector with the ith LDA eigenvector) show that ACs (such as FP) exhibit a well-defined approximately Gaussian structure in LDA space.

M. Temporal progression of the ACs within a sub-landscape comprising Early p3, p3, and FP identifies Early p3 as the initial (”head”) attractor from which cells transition to either p3 or FP. Grey dots represent all cells in the group (D5-D7), coloured dots indicate cells present at the indicated time points with the colour indicating their cluster assignment. Contour lines indicate the density of cells at each time point.

caption.title: Analysis of Cell State Transitions Using Unstable Manifolds Between Attractor Clusters.
caption.p: A. Illustration of a fold bifurcation with a potential. (Left) Cells remain in the attractor which sits at the bottom of the potential well. There is a saddle close, over which some cells might escape. The blue curve is the approximated unstable manifold of the saddle. Escaping cells will, subject to noise, travel along this. (Right) A change in parameters leads to the collision with the saddle and destruction of the attractor and saddle so that all cells escape. The blue curve is the unstable manifold along which cells escape.

B. An illustration of a binary flip landscape with a potential. Cells start in the left hand attractor and, if they escape, they transition along the blue approximate unstable manifold to the grey attractor at the top of the illustration. A change in the parameters can result in the unstable manifold flipping so that cells transition to the bottom right attractor (dark purple) instead of the top attractor (grey).

C. Bifurcation set of a binary flip landscape. When a change in parameters causes them to cross the fold curve, the NMP attractor undergoes a fold bifurcation (i.e. it collides with a nearby saddle and disappears). When a change in parameters causes them to cross the flip curve, the system undergoes a flip bifurcation in which the unstable manifold of the saddle close to the NMP attractor changes its connection, flipping from one attractor to the other. If the parameters are to the left of the fold-flip point (asterisk), then the unstable manifold (red) connects to the PreNeural attractor. If the system is to the right of the fold-flip point then the unstable manifold (blue) connects to the Early Mesoderm attractor. The stable manifolds (green) of each saddle partition the phase space into basins of attraction, each containing a single attractor and coloured accordingly.

D. Temporal progression of the NMP, PreNeural, Early Mesoderm and Mesoderm ACs in LDA coordinates. Grey dots represent all cells in the group, coloured dots indicate cells present at the indicated time points with the colours indicating their cluster assignment. Contour lines indicate the density of cells at each time point. This exemplifies the binary flip decision from NMP to PreNeural or to Early Mesoderm, followed by a direct transition from Early Mesoderm to Mesoderm. At D3 almost all cells (dots) are in the NMP AC. Cells in both PreNeural and Early Mesoderm (Tbx6+) are evident at D3.6, and increase at D3.8. There is then a direct transition from Early Mesoderm to Mesoderm at D3.8 and PreNeural empties as cells transition to other states (see SI Fig. S2G).

E. The two unstable manifolds (red and blue curves) for the landscapes of cells projected into LDA space. The red approximate unstable manifold outlines the route to PreNeural and the blue unstable manifold the route to Early Mesoderm and Mesoderm.

F. (Left) The unstable manifolds are estimated in the higher dimensional effective gene space. This avoids artificial ordering of the points along the curve that might occur if, for example, the LDA components were strongly determined by a single gene. This curve is then projected into the LDA space of interest (2D or 3D). (Right) Balls are placed along the projected curve in LDA space. Together they form a tubular neighbourhood of the unstable manifold. Raw counts of individual genes are averaged over the cells inside each ball to determine how gene expression changes along the unstable manifold (SI Sect. S3). This construction ensures that the change in expression levels does not depend upon the particular LDA projection used.

G. LDA plots of the binary flip decision from NMP to either PreNeural or Early Mesoderm using D3-D4 data showing the projected unstable manifolds. The positions of the balls is shown by the index of their centers.

H. The variation of key genes along the estimated unstable manifolds from G. Genes such as Cdx2, Sox2, Nkx1.2 and Tbx6 show diverging behaviour along the two routes consistent with the expected behaviour in a binary flip landscape.

I. Temporal progression of cells along the projected unstable manifolds in G. Proportions of cells (dots) at stages D3, D3.4, D3.6, and D4 within each ball along the unstable manifolds connecting NMP to Mesoderm (left) and NMP to PreNeural (right). We used a high smoothing factor to obtain smooth densities. In the right panel, there are very few cells at D4 (pink density) because cells at this stage have exited the PreNeural AC (SI Fig. S2G).

caption.title: Flow Cytometry Analysis of Cell States Reveals SAG Concentration-Dependent Neural Progenitor Specification.
caption.p: A. Schematic of the signalling conditions used for flow cytometry.
B. 2D PCA projection of the ACs found using flow cytometry data. Data for all SAG concentrations and time points are combined.

C. Dot plot indicating the expression of markers used to characterise the ACs in B (for the other clusters see SI Fig. S7B). The Floor Plate cluster (FP) was not identifiable in this dataset (see discussion in SI Sect. S5.2).

D. Percentage occupancy of the ACs as a function of Day (D) and SAG concentration (0, 10, 100, 500nM SAG). This shows the average proportions over 3 experimental replicates for 10nM and 100nM and 5 replicates for 0nM and 500nM (SI Sect. S4). The blank spaces in the bar plots correspond to the proportions of transitioning and unclassified cells and these are shown in SI Fig. S7C for all replicates.

E. 3D representation in LDA coordinates of the clusters at all time points (unclassified cells excluded). At 0nM SAG cells remain confined to the p0/p1 AC but start transitioning to p2 and pMN at 10nM SAG. The ventral cell branch (green/cyan dots) that includes EarlyVentral, Early p3, and p3 only appears at high SAG concentrations (100nM, 500nM).

F. Schematic diagrams of attractors present at different SAG levels and the connections between them. This represents the consensus state because a landscape is associated with an individual cell and these are heterogeneous in state and signal.

G-H. Temporal evolution of selected ACs (D4-D6) in LDA coordinates as a function of time and SAG concentration. Grey dots represent all cells in the group, coloured dots indicate cells present at the indicated time points with the colours indicating their cluster assignment. Contour lines indicate the density of cells at each time point.

G. Binary flip decision from PreNeural to either p0/p1 or EarlyVentral. The figure shows the concentrations 0nM, 500nM SAG (see SI Fig. S11A for other concentrations). Grey dots represent all cells in the group, coloured dots indicate cells present at the indicated time points with the colour indicating their cluster assignment. Contour lines indicate the density of cells at each time point. (Left) The p0/p1 AC is stable when SAG is absent (0nM) and there is no transition to EarlyVentral. (Right) The transition to EarlyVentral only appears at high SAG concentrations (100nM, 500nM). PreNeural, p0/p1, and EarlyVentral empty over three days at the highest SAG level (500nM). The attractors have bifurcated, but the unstable manifolds from PreNeural to pMN and Early p3 still pass through the regions in gene space formerly occupied by the bifurcated attractors.

H. Direct transitions from p2 to pMN and from pMN to MNDiff. The figure shows the concentrations 10nM, 500nM SAG (see SI Fig. S12A for other concentrations). (Left) At 10nM SAG, the p2 AC is relatively stable but shallow as cells can escape and transition to pMN over time. (Right) The same transition at 500nM SAG where p2 has already bifurcated showing more rapid occupation of the pMN AC.

caption.title: Global Landscape Model.
caption.p: A. A schematic diagram of all the identified transitions between cell states. A group of neighbouring ACs and transitioning cells is extracted from the data and then projected in LDA space. We highlighted the ACs belonging to the intermediate (yellow shaded) and the ventral sub-landscape (green shaded).

B. The projection in 3D LDA space of the intermediate sub-landscape highlighted in A. Unstable manifolds are approximated using splines in the higher-dimensional effective gene space and projected onto the 3D LDA space. Gene expression variations along these pathways reveal consistent patterns of lineage splitting.

C. We model the intermediate sub-landscape in A and B, by a parameterised family of local vectorfields (SI Sect. S6 Definition S6.1). The configuration of the sub-landscape’s attractors and unstable/stable manifolds depends upon the parameters and varies as parameters change in the different regions (marked by a-g) inside the rectangle. For the parameters controlling the transitions among the linear arrangement of the 4 attractors MNDiff, pMN, DP and p3, the bifurcation set consists of fold curves decorated with dual cusps in parameter space (one dual cusp in the rectangle).

D. Phase portrait of the global landscape for a fixed set of parameters when all attractors are present. The blue and green curves are respectively the unstable and stable manifolds of the various saddles. The green stable manifolds of the saddles separate the basins of attraction of the various attractors which are coloured accordingly. If the state of a reprogrammed cell falls in one of these coloured domains, it will converge towards the corresponding attractor and adopt that specific fate. In this figure we have arbitrarily chosen one direction for each flip bifurcation. 2D LDA plots of the ACs are shown for 4 of the 5 sub-landscapes.

E. Schematic of the simulation procedure, illustrated for the first two binary decisions (further transitions are not shown). For each cell µ, parameters for the individual sub-landscapes are selected within their respective parameter domains (two components in each 2D bifurcation panel represented by a dot coloured differently for each cell). Together, they form the components of a parameter vector θµ of the global landscape (illustrated here for 4 cells labelled A, B, C and D with parameters θA, θB, θC, θD). These parameters define the configuration of attractors, saddles and unstable manifolds of the cell’s deterministic dynamics. Adding stochastic fluctuations to these dynamics, we simulate a stochastic trajectory for each cell, recording their positions in state space at discrete time points. Each of the panels on the left shows the deterministic (local) landscape for each cell determined by their respective parameters. In each panel, the evolving cell is coloured according to its time step. Different set of parameters produce different landscape models resulting in distinct possible fates for each cell (dashed rectangles in each panel). If an attractor is present in a cell’s landscape (e.g PreNeural for cell D), the cell may remain trapped in this attractor as we see for the purple dots, indicating the position of the cell over time, staying near the PreNeural attractor. Expanding the parameter sampling allows the simulation of a large number of cells (central panel). Clustering the simulated cells identifies ACs (coloured according to the cell state they correspond to), and the proportion of cells in each AC at each time points were compared to the experimental data.

caption.title: Parameter Estimation and Bifurcation Analysis of the Dynamic Landscape Model.
caption.p: A. Experimental proportions (yellow background) compared to the simulated proportions (blue background) after parameter fitting for each SAG concentration using the flow cytometry data. The predicted FP proportions (12%) obtained from simulations at 500 nM SAG are consistent with the FP proportions observed in the scRNA-seq at the same SAG concentration in H below (7%). The experimental proportions were obtained by averaging the proportions for 3 individual experimental series for 10nM, 100nM and for 5 experimental series for 0nM and 500nM (SI Sect. S4).

B.-C. Dots represents parameters accepted by the ABC particle filter. Contour lines are used to estimate the PPDs projected on the corresponding sub-landscape parameter space (purple: 0nM, yellow: 10nM SAG, orange: 100nM, red: 500nM). The other curves show the bifurcation set where fold and flip bifurcations occur for the different sub-landscapes. PPDs projected on the other sub-landscapes parameter space can be found in SI Fig. S18A.

B. Bifurcation set of the sub-landscape controlling the p2 transition. The yellow fold curve represents the set of sub-landscape parameter values where the p2 attractor is eliminated in a fold bifucation. The PPD at 10nM SAG lies on both sides of the fold curve, suggesting that the p2 attractor is present, but shallow, for half of the cells and bifurcated for the other half in which case cells transition to a downstream attractor. This demonstrates that the p2 AC remains stable over time, and the leakage to pMN observed in Fig. 3H occurs either because a cell escapes from the p2 attractor or because its parameter fall outside of the shaded yellow region of the bifurcation set where the p2 attractor is bifurcated. At higher SAG concentrations (100nM, 500nM) the PPDs lie outside the shaded region suggesting that the p2 attractor is bifurcated for all cells. The 0nM PPD (purple) is not shown, as the parameter did not converge due to the absence of p2 cells at this SAG concentration (the parameters are distributed across the entire region).

C. Bifurcation set of the sub-landscape controlling the binary decision from PreNeural to a downstream attractor modelled by a binary flip. Parameters on opposite sides of the gray flip bifurcation curve give rise to distinct sub-landscape representatives: one with an unstable manifold (blue) connecting PreNeural to the p0/p1 attractor or, if p0/p1 is bifurcated, to an attractor part of the intermediate sublandscape and the other (red) connecting PreNeural to the next attractor, part of the ventral sub-landscape (Fig. 4A), that is present on the way down. When the purple fold curve is crossed, the PreNeural attractor bifurcates. Upon bifurcation, the cell’s fate is determined by the basin of attraction it was in, leading it to the downstream attractor belonging to this basin. At low SAG concentrations (0nM, 10nM) the PPDs are to the left of the flip bifurcation curve implying that most PreNeural cells transition towards p0/p1 or an intermediate state. At higher concentrations (100nM, 500nM) the PPDs cluster near the fold-flip point where the fold and the flip curves intersect. In this case, cells can transition to both intermediate and ventral states.

D. Examples of a cell’s landscape for three specific set of landscape parameters. The sub-landscape parameter components are indicated in B and C by the yellow, orange and red crosses which are in a high density region of one of the PPDs. The pMN attractor appears bifurcated away for this specific set of parameters, but it is present for other parameter values and remains accessible to other cells (see other parameters in SI Fig. S18A Panel 5).

E-F. Examples of dynamical configurations suggested by the fitting for the p2 transition from p2 to pMN/MNDiff or DP obtained by fixing specific landscape parameters values. A cell (yellow) that has just left the p2 attractor transitions along the blue unstable manifold to reach the pMN attractor.

E. The unstable manifold connects p2 to pMN with the latter well-separated from the saddle between it and DP. The saddle between pMN and MNDiff is close to pMN and therefore the cell can transition from pMN to MNDiff.
F. In this case, the pMN attractor is near bifurcation with its right saddle, thus when a cell reaches pMN, it is likely to jump over this saddle and move towards a DP fate.

G. Five stochastic single cell trajectories followed for 400 simulation timesteps and coloured according to the eventual fate. Gray dots indicate other cell trajectories, included to help visualise the shape of the landscape. Notice that while pseudotime makes sense for the transitioning segments of a trajectory, it does not make sense for a full trajectory because cells spend random long periods near attractors.

H. Distribution of the simulated proportions (coloured by cell state) retained by the ABC particle filter compared with the experimental proportions for the scRNA-seq dataset (percent values in decimal form). For each cell state, the thick blue curve represents the experimental proportions and the dashed curve represents the mean of the simulated proportions. Shaded region indicates 95% confidence interval for the simulated proportions.

caption.title: Experimental Validation of Model Predictions Through Signalling Perturbations.
caption.p: A. Simulated data showing the attractors and transition routes. Dots represent simulated cells retained at 3 time points (D4, D5, D6). These are aggregated into simulated ACs coloured by the cell state to which they correspond.

B. PPDs from model fitting for the 500nM SAG condition (blue) and the post-high-SAG condition (red) are close to identical, revealing that the two conditions are approximately equivalent. (Left) Projection of the PPDs on the bifurcation set of the binary flip sub-landscape. (Right) Projection of the PPDs on the bifurcation set of the linear sub-landscape.

C. Comparison of average simulation results (blue background) for the constant SAG conditions with the corresponding experimental results (yellow background). Results are average over 10000 simulated proportions using parameters drawn from the fitted PPDs (SI Sect. S12).

D. As C but for the Up-SAG0/500 condition. The prediction aligns with the experimental data. It shows that delaying SAG application by 24h commits the cells to differentiate into pMN∗ rather than p3∗.

E. As C but for the Down-SAG500/0 condition but modified as follows: (middle) uses the fitted PPDs (500nM and 0nM SAG) obtained from H, (right) uses the refitted PPD. The latter shows better agreement with the experimental results.

F. As for the first two panels of E for the Down-SAG100/0 condition but where the fitted PPDs (100nM and 0nM SAG) obtained from C are used. We observe the same phenomenon as in E (middle panel), despite lower levels of the signal.

G. (Top) Local view of a cell’s landscape near the DP and p3 attractors where the DP-to-p3 transition occurs. The p3 attractor can be reached via two distinct pathways: an intermediate route (yellow), following the unstable manifold which passes through the DP attractor and connects to p3 from the left, and a ventral route (green), following the unstable manifold which passes through the Early p3 attractor and connects to p3 from the right. Each route is characterised by different gene expression profiles. Cells transitioning through the intermediate route have a history of Olig2 expression, whereas cells following the ventral route express Foxa2 early at D4. (Bottom) Local view of simulated ACs (500nM SAG condition) at D7, capturing the DP-to-p3 transition. Each dot represents a single cell. The cells that reached DP (brown) had their dynamics locally governed by a dynamical system as shown above where there is a well defined intermediate route. A few cells remain in the pMN AC but the majority of pMN cell have transition into motor neurons or DP.

H. (Left) Simulated cell trajectories using the PPD from model fitting (500nM SAG condition). Dots represent simulated cells retained at 4 time points (D4-D7). Cells reaching the p3 AC by D7 are coloured based on their transition history: yellow for cells that follow the intermediate route and green for those that follow the ventral route. Black dots represent cells that adopted alternative end fates (such as MNDiff or FP) or have not yet reached p3 by D7. (Right) Same setup, but with pulsing applied in the simulation by switching the parameters from 0 nM to 500 nM after D4. Significantly fewer cells opt for the ventral route as most cells had already taken the intermediate route by D4 when the signal changed, as in D.

I. Proportions of simulated cells in the p3 AC for each day (D5 to D7) computed with respect to the total number of p3 cells at D7 and coloured by the route they originate from as in H. (Left) 500nM condition, (Right) Up-SAG0/500nM condition. The majority of p3 cells under this latter condition originate from the intermediate route.

J. Histograms showing cell counts (y-axis) by the time point (x-axis) at which simulated cells first reach the p3 AC, with colours indicating their route of origin: intermediate (yellow) or ventral route (green). The distributions reflect timing heterogeneity: cells that reach p3 via the intermediate route tend to arrive at late time points (D6-D7). By contrast, cells following the ventral route tend to reach p3 early (D4-D5) while few new cells arrive via this route after D6.

K. 2D Gene plots (Olig2-Nkx2.2 shown) of the clusters identified in the flow cytometry dataset at each time point. The dots represent individual cells, and contour lines represent the density of cells (plotted only when the cluster contains more than 150 cells). Without the Nkx6.1 marker p0/p1 cannot be distinguished from p2 cells and both are combined into Pax6+ cells, and PreNeural from EarlyVentral and FP are combined into Sox2+ cells. (Top) 500nM SAG condition: as early as D4, a group of cells take the ventral route by up-regulating Nkx2.2 and reach p3 by D5. (Bottom) Up-SAG0/500nM condition: with no SAG for 24h, cells are forced to take the intermediate route and most of them had up-regulated Pax6 by D4. When SAG is applied, they can only reach p3 by transiting through pMN (D5), then DP (D6), followed by a direct DP-to-p3 transition (D7).
L. (Top left) 500nM SAG condition: experimental proportions of the DP AC and p3Trans (intermediate route) and the Early p3 and p3 ACs (ventral route) at late time points (D5-D7).

(Top right) 500nM SAG condition: simulated proportions of the DP, Early p3 and p3 ACs at late time points (D5-D7). The p3 proportions can be further split into two type of cells depending on which route they come from as in I. (Bottom) Same as above for the Up-SAG0/500nM condition. In the simulation (bottom right), most p3 cells at D7 originate from the intermediate route as shown in I (right) which is consistent with the experiment (K bottom).

caption.title: Comparative Analysis of Human Neural Progenitor Development Validates the Circular Topology of the Decision Landscape
caption.p: A. Summary of the outward clustering methodology.
B. The most significantly differentially expressed genes found using the 4 samples defined in A.
C. The four cell type domains including neural progenitors were extracted, annotated and separately projected using LDA from the effective gene space defined by the gene modules in B.
D. 3D LDA projection of the Neural Progenitor ACs across all time points and all experimental conditions. The topological structure reveals the circular topology of the transition pathways.

E. Simulated Neural Progenitors ACs produced by the landscape model of this system after fitting in a similar fashion to that described above. Dots represents simulated cells retained at 3 time points corresponding to D3, D5, D7 using the parameters from the fitted PPDs for the 18h-Delay condition. Gray dots represent transitioning cells that were not assigned to any simulated AC.
E. Dot plot indicating the expression of markers used to identify the tissue domains. The intensity of shading indicates the mean expression of each gene in each domain.
G. Proportions of cells in each domain of C and F by time points under the two experimental conditions.
H. Dot plot indicating the expression of markers used to identify the ACs and transitioning clusters of the Neural Progenitors domain in C.

I.-J. PreNeural sub-landscape extracted from the human dataset (I) and the mouse datasets (J) and transition analysis for marker genes that characterise the binary decision as cells exit PreNeural. Unstable manifolds defining routes between pairs of ACs where computed in effective gene space defined by the genes in B and projected onto 2D LDA space. Marker genes were analysed along both routes. Exit from PreNeural is marked by down-regulation of Cdx2 and Nkx1.2. A branching event occurs (around index 10), followed by up-regulation of markers characteristic of ventral states along the red route (leading to EarlyVentral), and markers such as Pax6 characteristic of the intermediate states p0/p1, and p2 along the blue route.

K. (Top) Experimental compared to simulated proportions after parameter fitting for the 18h-Delay condition. (Bottom) Same as above for the 24h-Delay condition. It shows an increase of ventral states such as p3 and FP.

L. Bifurcation set of the PreNeural binary flip shows the qualitative difference between the 18h- and the 24h-Delay conditions. The 18h-Delay PPD (blue) cluster on the left of the flip curve and above the PreNeural fold curve. Under this condition, the PreNeural attractor is shallow for most cells and is connected to p0/p1. By contrast, the 24h-Delay PPD (red) lies to the right of the flip curve, favouring cell trajectories from PreNeural to EarlyVentral and promoting the generation of more p3 and FP cells.

M. Typical configurations of attractors, saddles and unstable manifolds for the cell landscape models for the PreNeural sub-landscape for parameters in each of the PPDs in L. In the 18h-Delay, cells are most likely to transition via the intermediate route towards p2 and to Early p3 via the ventral route in the 24h-Delay. As indicated by the PPDs in N, the attractors p0/p1 and EarlyVentral are bifurcated for all cells in both experimental conditions. Hence the connections from PreNeural lead directly to p2 (blue unstable manifold) or to Early p3 (red unstable manifold).
N. Bifurcation set of the p2 transition shows that, under both conditions, the p2 AC is shallow as most parameters cluster near (and above) the p2 fold curve.

O. Bifurcation set of the circular sub-landscape controlling the p0/p1 and EarlyVentral fold bifurcations. Under both conditions, the PPDs are well-separated from the blue shaded region where the p0/p1 and the EarlyVentral attractors are bifurcated for all cells. It shows in particular that the p0/p1 and EarlyVentral ACs are not stable.
